results.title: Carphone Warehouse in mobile talks with Three
results.content:
Carphone Warehouse is in advanced talks with Three, the British mobile operator, to launch its own branded mobile services following the retail chain's merger with Dixons.

Carphone Warehouse, which will be renamed Dixons Carphone, would buy wholesale access to Three's network to provide the services, reports the FT's Dan Thomas.

Executives at the group have indicated that they want to explore the opportunity around the wider connectivity of electrical devices such as cameras and white goods alongside the more traditional means of communication such as smartphones and tablets.

The merger with Dixons has put this so-called "internet of things" at the heart of the future strategy of the combined group.

Carphone Warehouse currently has a "branded reseller" agreement with Vodafone at present where the customers belong to the mobile operator rather than the retailer.

There are about 700,000 customers that use this low cost alternative at present.

Carphone Warehouse has been reviewing this relationship ahead of the completion of the merger with Dixons in order to see how extra services could be added. It is not clear what will happen to its arrangement with Vodafone in future.

Carphone Warehouse has spoken to other mobile operators, according to one person familiar with the situation, although the group's talks with Three are progressing. The group is also examining a similar arrangement in Ireland. Carphone Warehouse and Three declined to comment.

Carphone Warehouse is not seen as a direct competitor by mobile operators, according to one person with knowledge of the situation, because the retailer targets specific customer areas.

Carphone Warehouse's primary business will continue to be selling service contracts for the main mobile operators who offer customers smartphones and tablets through the chain's stores.
results.abstract: Carphone Warehouse is in advanced talks with Three, the British mobile operator, to launch its own branded mobile services following the retail chain's merger with Dixons.

results.title: Buoyant bond market opens its doors
results.content:
Macedonia has launched its first bond sale in five years as lowly rated countries rush to take advantage of the ravenous appetite for higher yielding debt.

The Ivory Coast also opened books on its bond market return this morning, and Senegal is expected later this week, as the buoyant bond market opens to everyone regardless of their size, health or credit history.

Macedonia is selling a seven-year euro denominated bond, with orders being taken today and the final price expected tomorrow. Deutsche Bank and HSBC are arranging the deal, after taking a delegation of the country's officials on a roadshow to meet European investors.

The Balkan country handed the governing centre-right party another electoral mandate in April, after it helped Macedonia carve out a niche as a small European manufacturing and services hub. Macedonia is rated BB- by Standard& Poor's and BB+ by Fitch – in the "junk" range of ratings.
results.abstract: Macedonia has launched its first bond sale in five years as lowly rated countries rush to take advantage of the ravenous appetite for higher yielding debt.

results.title: UK: unemployment drops again, wage growth slows
results.content:
The UK's headline rate of unemployment moved lower again as the proportion of people in work matched its highest ever level.

The jobless rate fell to 6.5 per cent in the three months ended in May, matching economists' forecasts and down from 6.6 per cent for the previous three-month period.

The number of people claiming unemployment benefits also fell sharply, down 36,000 in June versus forecasts of only a 27,000 person drop, according to data from the official statistics agency, the Office for National Statistics.

That's the good news.

Far less positive was the data on wages, showing that average weekly earnings growth slowed to an anaemic 0.3 per cent - the lowest level since May 2009 and down from a revised figure of 0.8 per cent for the three months ended in April.

Economists had expected that wage growth would pick up as capacity in the labour market declined. . The ONS reported on Wednesday that the proportion of people aged from 16 to 64 in work, known as the employment rate, reached 73.1% for the three months ended in May.

The last time it reached that level was the three months ended in February 2005, and has never been higher since records began in 1971.

results.title: Ivory Coast returns to the bond markets
results.content:
The Ivory Coast has launched a 10-year international bond sale and is looking for a yield around the 5.875 per cent area - just three years after it was thrown into default by the violent upheaval that followed elections that year.

The country had initially indicated that it would only look to make a more careful return to the bond market with a five-year offering, but such is the demand for "frontier" countries - and African ones in particular - that the deal maturity has been doubled.

Even with the longer maturity, the 5.875 per cent yield guided by bankers is remarkably low for a country with a somewhat checkered credit history.

Yet the Ivory Coast won plaudits for how it handled the post-election default and investors sitting on cash and looking at the historically low yields in the developed world have little choice but to search out more exotic bonds to hit their return targets.

Bankers threw open the order books this morning and are aiming for at least $500m.
results.abstract: The Ivory Coast has launched a 10-year international bond sale and is looking for a yield around the 5.875 per cent area - just three years after it was thrown into default by the violent upheaval that followed elections that year.

results.title: European ABS market continues to stutter
results.content:
The volume of "slice and diced" loans in Europe sold to investors has fallen, in spite of increasingly loud calls to revive the region's stigmatized securities market in order to boost economic growth.

Asset-backed securities – which take loan revenues from assets such as mortgages or credit cards and bundle them up for sale to fixed-income investors – placed in the open market fell by 6 per cent to €19.4bn year-on-year in the second quarter, according to figures from the Association for Financial Markets in Europe, reports the FT's Chris Thompson.

Last year's total issued ABS, at €76.4bn, was the lowest since 2009 when the asset became a bête noire among many regulators and investors.

Overall ABS issuance grew year on year by 43 per cent to €95.1bn, although 80 per cent of it was used as collateral to access central bank funds, highlighting how institutions such as the European Central Bank dominate the market.

"There is plenty of demand out there for high quality securitization but it's hard for investors to get hold of it," said Richard Hopkin, managing director at AFME. "The message is that the market is still heavily dependent on central bank funding for support and the much lower cost of funding via the central banks is making the private sector bid uncompetitive."

Securitization is used as a funding tool by banks and also to transfer risky assets off their balance sheets.

Slightly over 60 per cent of ABS issuance was pledged to central banks over the same period in 2013.

Over the past year there have been increasingly vocal calls from senior policy makers, including those at the ECB and Bank of England, for a revival of Europe's securitization market which was widely blamed for exacerbating the financial crisis between 2008-9.

Full story on ft.com
results.abstract: The volume of "slice and diced" loans in Europe sold to investors has fallen, in spite of increasingly loud calls to revive the region's stigmatized securities market in order to boost economic growth.

results.title: European markets climb after China data, Yellen
results.content:
European markets were gainng at the open, as investors digest the latest comments on the health of the economy from Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen yesterday and following slightly better than expected growth data out of China.

  • The FTSE Eurofirst 300 edged up 0.57 per cent to 1,366.12.
  • Portugal's PSI is up 1.14 per cent at 6,181.29.
  • In the UK, the FTSE100 index is up 0.51 per cent at 6,744.54.
  • Italy's FTSE MIB edged up 0.62 per cent to 20,546.64
  • The Ibex in Spain is up 0.43 per cent to 10,520.30 points.
  • Germany's Dax is up 0.49 per cent to 9,767,44.

The performance of momentum plays such as social media and biotech stocks are likely to be in focus after the Fed warned on Tuesday that valuations "appear to be stretched".

The US monetary guardian's intervention came alongside testimony from Ms Yellen, in which she stressed that "considerable uncertainty" over the outlook for the US economy would make it difficult to pinpoint the timing of future interest rate rises.

Traders are also responding to the latest GCP data out China, showing the economy expanded at an annualised pace of 7.5 per cent in the second quarter, after policy makers relied on economic stimulus measures to shore up growth.

That puts the economy on track to hit the government's 7.5 per cent GDP target for the full year, after a 7.4 per cent reading in Q1.
results.abstract: European markets were gainng at the open, as investors digest the latest comments on the health of the economy from Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen yesterday and following slightly better than expected growth data out of China.

results.title: Portugal Telecom lowers Oi stake in merger
results.content:
Here's the latest from Portugal from the FT's Peter Wise, as turmoil continues to swirl around the troubled Espirito Santo group.

Portugal Telecom has agreed to lower its stake in a planned merger with Brazil's Oi after Rioforte, one of Espirito Santo's holding companies, defaulted on a €847m commercial paper repayment to the Portuguese telecoms group.

The stake is to be reduced to 25.6 per cent from a planned 39.6 per cent after PT reached an agreement with Oi to exchange the Rioforte debt for what it called Oi ON shares and Oi Call shares.

In a statement on Wednesday, PT said the two companies "remain committed to the full completion of their business combination" for which they had signed a new memorandum of understanding.

PT revealed last month that it was holding €897m in Rioforte treasury securities, €847m of which matured on Tuesday. The Rioforte debt is held by PT subsidiaries that were contributed to Oi in May as part of the planned merger, which was due to be completed in October.

Doubts over the merger arose when Oi challenged PT over its investment in Rioforte's three-month commercial paper, saying it had not been aware of the purchase.

The PT-Oi agreement comes amid unconfirmed reports that Rioforte is preparing to ask for protection from its creditors to prevent insolvency proceedings that would force it into immediate asset sales.

The Espírito Santo group is the biggest shareholder in Banco Espírito Santo, the Portuguese lender whose shares hit an all-time low on Tuesday after falling more than 62 per cent in a month on fears over its exposure to the Espírito Santo family group's liabilities.

Shares have recovered on Wednesday, trading up about 8 per cent in Lisbon.

BES has owned about 10 per cent of PT for several years and helped the telecoms group in its tussle [http://www.ft.com/...?siteedition=intl] with Spain's Telefónica over their jointly-owned Brazilian mobile unit Vivo in 2010.

Rioforte is fully owned by Espirito Santo International, the Luxembourg-based parent company for the group holdings that has missed some payments on commercial paper. Rioforte fully owns Espirito Santo Irmaos, which holds 49 per cent of Espírito Santo Financial Group. ESFG in turn owns 20.1 per cent of BES.
results.abstract: Here's the latest from Portugal from the FT's Peter Wise, as turmoil continues to swirl around the troubled Espirito Santo group.

results.title: IPOs float revenues at LSE
results.content:
London calling.

A resurgent IPO market helped push total revenues up 20 per cent at the London Stock Exchange group, .

Total income rose 16 per cent to £324m for the three months ended in June, the stock exchange operator said on Wednesday, with its capital markets business, its largest division, driving growth amid a wave of new listings.

Said Xavier Rolet, chief executive:

We have been pleased by the continued resurgence in the IPO market with an increase both in the number of companies joining our markets and the amount of money raised.

The group agreed at the end of June to buy Russell Investments for $2.7bn in cash, widening its presence in the US. The rights issue is expected in late August.

So far, there's been a fairly muted reaction by shareholders. LSE was trading mostly flat, up 0.35 per cent at £19.53.
results.abstract:
London calling.

A resurgent IPO market helped push total revenues up 20 per cent at the London Stock Exchange group, .

results.title: Royal Mail, TNT face French antitrust probe
results.content:
Royal Mail, the UK postal operator that floated last year, has warned of a possible "material" loss in connection with a French competition investigation into one of its subsidiaries.

In an unscheduled statement released on Wednesday, Royal Mail said it had received a notice from France's main competition authority alleging antitrust law violations by its GLS France unit.

Here's the statement in full (emphasis ours):

Royal Mail plc (RMG.L) announces that certain group companies have received a notice from the French competition authority (Autorité de la Concurrence) alleging breaches of antitrust laws by one of its subsidiaries, GLS France.

This is in connection with a broader investigation into alleged activities within the industry in France.

We are currently considering the notice received from the French regulator. Given the early stage of this matter, we cannot yet determine the amount or range of potential loss; however, it is possible that it could be material.

An update will be provided at the appropriate time.

GLS is Royal Mail's ground-based, 2-3 day parcel delivery service in Europe. According to the group, around 1,940 long-haul trucks are on Europe's roads for GLS on a daily basis.

And it's not the only parcels company to disclose a competition probe in France.

From Dutch rival TNT Express. also on Wednesday:

TNT Express has received a Statement of Objections (SO) from the French Competition Authority with respect to alleged anti-competitive behaviour in the French parcels delivery sector, including TNT Express France. TNT Express has cooperated with the investigation since it started in 2010.

On the basis of preliminary analysis of the SO, it cannot be excluded that TNT Express will be fined for a material amount as a result of this procedure.

And from US-based delivery giant FedEx in its annual 10-K filing on Monday (page 68 for those who like detail):

On June 30, 2014, we received a Statement of Objections from the French Competition Authority ("FCA") addressed to FedEx Express France, formerly known as TATEX, regarding an investigation by the FCA into anticompetitive behavior that is alleged to have occurred primarily in the framework of trade association meetings that included the former general managers of TATEX prior to our acquisition of that company in July 2012.

Given the early stage of this matter, we cannot yet determine the amount or range of potential loss; however, it is reasonably possible that it could be material.

results.abstract: Royal Mail, the UK postal operator that floated last year, has warned of a possible "material" loss in connection with a French competition investigation into one of its subsidiaries.

results.title: Sports Direct's Ashley declines bonus plan award
results.content:
Poor Mike Ashley.

In an unexpected twist, the founder of UK sportswear chain Sports Direct has now withdrawn from a £200mcompany bonus scheme, even after shareholders voted through the plan at a brief meeting earlier this month.

From a statement from Sports Direct on Wednesday:

Sports Direct International plc ("Sports Direct" or the "Group"), the UK's leading sports retailer, announces that Mike Ashley, Executive Deputy Chairman of Sports Direct, after discussion with the Remuneration Committee, has informed the Board that he does not wish to be awarded any shares under the 2015 Bonus Share Scheme.

This follows the approval of the resolution by a clear majority of independent shareholders on 2 July 2014 to implement the 2015 Bonus Share Scheme.

Media reports had suggested that leading Sports Direct investors were planning coordinated action against the company's board following the move to approve the contentious plan, including voting against the re-election of the chairman and other board members at September's annual general meeting

The scheme would have allowed Mr Ashley to split as much as £200m in shares with "all eligible" employees if certain profit targets were hit, as the retailer launched its third attempt in two years to give its majority shareholder a bonus.

Said Sports Direct chairman Keith Hellawell:

The resolution passed by shareholders to implement the 2015 Bonus Share Scheme clearly recognises the success of previous company-wide schemes, and the significant contribution from Mike.

On behalf of the entire Board, I should like to thank shareholders for the trust and confidence that they have demonstrated towards the team. Mike remains fully committed to achieving the scheme's stretch targets.

Regarding the allocation of shares, Mike's focus is on ensuring that the scheme aligns all employees to achieve the Company's objectives. Following recent unhelpful speculation surrounding his potential allocation, he is determined to ensure that there is the maximum number of shares available for the eligible employees.
results.abstract:
Poor Mike Ashley.

In an unexpected twist, the founder of UK sportswear chain Sports Direct has now withdrawn from a £200mcompany bonus scheme, even after shareholders voted through the plan at a brief meeting earlier this month.
